sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: This is Euronews tonight. Here are your top stories.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Fighting continues in Ukraine with strikes on Kyiv and 10 people killed queuing for bread in Chernihiv.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: President Zelensky calls on US Congress for more support.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Today the Ukrainian people are defending not only Ukraine, we are fighting for the values of Europe and the world.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Here in the queue, we look at a fake viral video which claims to show President Zelensky calling on Ukrainians to surrender.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: I'm in a huge relief, huge relief that she's on a plane, that she's coming home.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: And free at last after years in Iranian prisons, Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe and Anousheh Ashouri are allowed to return to their families in the UK.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: I'm Helena Humphrey. Thanks for joining me.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Fighting continues across Ukraine as the war enters its 21st day, but reports suggest that Moscow and Kiev are moving closer to a peace settlement.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Well, the capital was once again targeted by Russian shelling on Wednesday. But reports suggest that Moscow and Kyiv are moving closer to a peace settlement.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: The capital was once again targeted by Russian shelling on Wednesday.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Ukraine's state emergency services say that two people were injured and 37 evacuated after a missile strike on a residential building.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: In the city of Chernihiv, 10 people were reportedly killed as they waited in line for bread.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Close to 30,000 people have managed to escape the besieged city of Mariupol through humanitarian corridors. The city has been surrounded by Russian forces for the past two weeks and water and food supplies are reportedly running low. City officials say that up to 2,300 people have been killed by Russian missile strikes. During a speech to US Congress, President Zelensky called for a no-fly zone to thwart Russia's ability to rage war from the air.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: They used drones to kill us with precision.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: This is a terror that Europe has not seen, has not seen for 80 years, and we are asking for a reply, for an answer to this terror from the whole world. I have a need. I need to protect our sky. I need your decision, your help, which means exactly the same, the same you feel when you hear the words, I have a dream.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Well, let's go straight to Kyiv then that is a city which is currently under curfew we can bring in our international correspondent Annalise Borges. Annalise good to see you strikes have continued there in the capital so what is the latest that you can tell us? Indeed the Ukrainian capital is under curfew and still very much a city under attack.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Throughout the day today, we heard the sounds of relentless shelling and, of course, those air raid sirens.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: And, as you said, emergency responders did rush to one residential area that was hit once again.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: At least two people were injured.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Once again, at least two people were injured.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: That is, of course, after at least five Kiev residents were killed in such shellings in the space of 48 hours, which triggered the mayor of Kiev, Vitaly Klitschko, to announce this 35-hour curfew,

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: saying that these are dangerous times for the Ukrainian capital.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: So throughout the day today, people had to stay home.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: And many of them rushed to spaces like this one.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: As you can tell, this used to be a parking lot and has been converted into a bomb shelter.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: And across the city, spaces like this, basements, metro stations, have now become these bunkers to offer protection for the residents who remain here. This is the parking space of my hotel and many of the staff here have been living here since the start of the war, unwilling or unable to return home.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: So Annelies, as all of that goes on, President Zelensky is continuing to deliver these global addresses, most recently speaking to the US Congress.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: What were his main messages and how are those messages being received there in Ukraine, where you are?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Well, Zelensky's main message is that Ukrainians are currently fighting not only for their country, but also for the values of the free world and risking their lives and their future in the process.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: While addressing the U.S. Congress, he sent a message to his U.S. counterpart, President Joe Biden, saying it is time for Joe Biden to step up to the task of being the leader of the world and champion peace.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Volodymyr Zelensky, who has been addressing the world and his people over the last few days and weeks with the same message that they will resist, that Ukrainians are on Ukrainian land and they have the right to defend their country.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: He also said that Ukraine's destiny is currently being decided. And indeed, we've heard some progress on those peace negotiations.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: A fourth round of negotiations between Russian negotiators and Ukrainian negotiators is currently underway. And there are reports of a 15-point plan that was apparently drafted by those negotiators.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Under that agreement, Kyiv would have to accept neutrality, so would have to reportedly give up on its NATO bid, but also renounce any kind of foreign military support and also sign a deal saying there would be no military bases here in this country. The Ukrainian presidency had said that that would not be something that they would accept. However, just a few hours ago, we've heard from Zelensky that there could be a chance for that to happen if Ukraine would decide on its own terms of neutrality. Once again, we are still waiting to hear confirmation about those reports, but indeed there seems to be some suggestion of some kind of progress. Under that deal, of course, there would be a ceasefire and the withdrawal of Russian troops from Ukrainian territory.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: And that is very important because any plan that would see Russia take control of the areas that they have captured since February 24th would be perceived as a defeat here in Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: And many analysts have been saying that that would lead to no lasting peace for now at least the Ukrainian president has been already celebrating one victory uh Vladimir zelensky has tweeted celebrating the decision by the U.N's top court that has announced they have decided that Russia should suspend its military operations here in this country immediately that decision of course is binding however it's unclear how the U.N General Assembly and the U.N Security Council which Russia presides will enforce that all right our international correspondent in Kyiv Annalise Borges running us through all those latest developments Annalise thank you.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Well, let's get more now on the U.S. reaction to President Zelensky's address to Congress.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: I'm joined by Ray Suarez, who is in Washington, D.C.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Ray, this was very much an emotional address to U.S. lawmakers.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: He evoked U.S. history to get his message across.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: But when it comes down to it, how far will they go in granting the Ukrainian president his wishes? Well, Helena, as you say, he invoked American history, American heroes, and the speech was constructed to aim both at the head and at the heart. Volodymyr Zelensky talked practically about how to help Ukraine, had to thank the American people, the American taxpayer, the national legislature, and the American president for the aid that Ukraine has received so far, and then pivot immediately, say it wasn't enough and that, in order for his country to prevail, he needed much more, much more military support. And he continued to ask for that no-fly zone over the skies of Ukraine, that there seems to be very little sentiment, very little support in Congress or in the White House a couple of blocks in the other direction, to give him. So, a very subtle thing he tried to do today, say, thank you, but I need much more.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: And opinion seems to be coalescing in that building behind me, both in the House and the Senate, among Democrats and Republicans, that more should be on the way. By the end of today, that more should be on the way. By the end of today, Ukraine will have gotten $1 billion more in American aid, both humanitarian and military. We'll see what's still in the pipeline.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Helena?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Ray, you mentioned that address appealing to the heart and then also to the head. And I thought it was interesting to see that President Zelensky then switched to English, and he seemed to appeal directly to President Biden, saying, quoting here, you are the leader of the nation.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: I wish you to be the leader of the world, to be the leader of peace.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: And is this an effort to see more U.S. leadership, do you think, in this international response?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: DAVID BROOKS, Former U.S. Ambassador to the United States, Well, President Zelensky, as a former TV star, understands the world of modern communications.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: And he was very well aware that he wasn't only speaking to 435 members of the House of Representatives and 100 members of the Senate.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Of course, there was the big audience in the Oval Office of the White House, the audience of one Joe Biden.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: But he also knows that portion of the speech that was in English will be repeated over and over again, hour after hour, throughout the next news cycle, both on social media and on all American TV news outlets.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: He's speaking directly to the American people and their leaders, saying that this is not just a battle for Ukraine, a place most of them have never been, have no connection to, and will probably get anywhere near in their lifetimes. This is a battle for Europe and a battle for freedom in the world.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: By broadening Ukraine's struggle and speaking directly to the American people, he hopes to make even more progress, which is something, given the remarkable amount of consensus he's been able to build around supporting Ukraine just in the past month. Indeed, Ray Suarez in Washington, D.C. Good to have your insights, Ray. Thank you. Well, two dual U.K.-Iranian nationals have been released from prison in Tehran.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: They are heading home.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe and Anousheh Ashoury will be reunited with their families later.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Now, Nazanin was arrested in 2016 and imprisoned after being accused of plotting to overthrow Iran's government.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Anousheh was accused of spying for Israel's Mossad agency.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Nazanin's husband, Richard, and daughter and daughter Gabriella cannot wait to get her home.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: I'm relieved that the problem's been solved. I think the government has two jobs.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Protect people in situations like this to make sure it doesn't happen again.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Part of that is to doing what you need to do to get people home and part of that is to making sure those who took part learn the lesson not to continue doing it.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: That second part is for another day but for today I'm really glad the way things are.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: It's going to be lovely to see her, it's going to be lovely to catch up with her. We've chosen which toys we're taking so that she can get to see them and yeah, looking forward to a new life.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Well, covering this story for us from London is Vinnie McAvinny. We can go over to him now. Vinnie, this has been a long time coming. Talk us through what Nazanin and Nushe have faced and what their families have faced as well. Well, for Nazanin, this is the end of a journey of six years. In 2016, she went to the airport in Tehran expecting to be able to fly home. She's a dual British-Iranian citizen, but she was stopped and arrested and then her life turned into chaos. She's a dual British Iranian citizen. But she was stopped and arrested, and then her life turned into chaos. She was accused by the Iranian authorities of being there, of working in the country to undermine the government, their accusations, lying that she was a spy, that she was doing all kinds of things which were completely untrue.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: And then she was sentenced to this jail sentence. And then, over the last couple of years, she's been repeatedly used as a to support going into jail, being moved into solitary confinement, being released to her parents, then going back to jail when more charges appeared that were malicious.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: So it has been an incredibly difficult time for her.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Her daughter, Gabriela, for the first part, was looked after by her grandparents there in Iran, and then she was able to come home, and you saw her there with Richard, Nazanin's husband. Now, Richard is someone who has campaigned tirelessly. He is someone I've interviewed every few weeks, I think, for the last six years, because he's done protests outside the embassy. He's done a hunger strike. He's done everything possible to keep Nazanin's case in the limelight, to keep the pressure on successive governments to try to negotiate to get her home. And he was dissuaded from doing this at the start, but thankfully it has now worked. And we know Nazanin is on the way home. Now, the other one that you mentioned there, Anousheh Ashouri, he is someone as well, a British Iranian citizen who's a civil engineer visiting Iran and five years ago was arrested, accused of being a spy for Mossad, the Israeli intelligence agency. His family have also campaigned to bring him home, and they are very relieved as well that he is on his way back. But both of these people have been maliciously used by the Iranian regime in order to negotiate with Britain on other issues, geopolitical issues that are pretty sensitive.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: So it has been a difficult time for all the families involved in getting their loved ones home.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Yeah, Vinny, I just want to pick you up on that, saying that they were used as a pawn, because we know that the UK government now says that it has settled a debt owed to Iran from the 1970s. And I think it's fair to say that there will be questions about why it took until now.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Well this is a historical case of tanks so it was about a contract for military tanks that the Shah of Iran had bought the UK had started delivering on them but then the revolution happened and the UK government wouldn't fulfill the rest of the contract and kept the money because they didn't want to be handing it back to the Ayatollahs. So this is something the British government has long said the money was being kept in reserve and that perhaps it would be paid one day. But now in the past couple of years, the Iranians have then kidnapped people like Nazanin and also many others who sort of decided, the families have decided for various reasons to keep the cases quiet in the hope that that will help bring them home. But the UK government has finally, and it has been, you know, multiple foreign secretaries have been negotiating this for years. They have agreed to give this money and they've had the reassurances now that these people will be returned home. All right, Vinnie McAvinnie in London reporting on what is a huge day for those families.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Vinnie, thank you.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: NATO Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg says the alliance will bolster its defence forces as war intensifies in Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Following a meeting of defence ministers in Brussels, the NATO chief said the alliance will strengthen its capabilities across all areas.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: He also warned Moscow that NATO won't accept any attack on its territory.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Today, we tasked our military commanders to develop options across all domains, land, air, sea, cyber and space. On land, our new posture should include substantially more forces in the eastern part of the Alliance, at higher readiness, with more pre-positioned equipment and supplies.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Tracking that meeting for us, our correspondent Shona Murray in Brussels.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Shona, good to see you.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Listening to the NATO Secretary-General there, it seems that the alliance is set to play a bigger role than before, particularly when it comes to Eastern Europe. Well, indeed, yeah, I mean, we heard from Jens Stoltenberg there making the point that Europe has to reset its collective defence for obvious reasons. And we've seen huge, massive troop deployments to Europe's eastern flank. But I'm joined now by Michail Baranowski, a security expert in Warsaw for the German Marshall Fund. Michail, one of the things that, you know, you're in obviously Poland, a lot of countries are calling for, including Ukraine, is either a no-fly zone or for NATO to take a stand and engage in the conflict in Ukraine, even without, let's say, an Article 5 trigger.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Would that be possible?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Is there a legal way, given what we're seeing in Ukraine, bombing of maternity hospitals, the targeting of civilians and so on?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Well, let's start with the fact that the war in Ukraine, Russia's war in Ukraine, is very much illegal.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: So, of course, the alliance would have the moral ground to support Ukraine. There is also a Budapest memorandum that obliged United States, Great Britain, but also Russia to guarantee security of Ukraine. So there is plenty of legal basis. The reason why the alliance is hesitant and has not decided to to do that at this point is a threat of confrontation directly between nato's forces and russian forces and possible escalation even including a nuclear dimension by russia um and do you think it could be inevitable that you will find NATO engaging, though, given, as we said, you know, that people assume that really the retaliation or the attacks from Russia are just going to get worse. So maybe that if you prolong it, prolong the inevitable, you'll just have higher death toll. I'm not sure if it's inevitable. It's true that Russia is incredibly brutal, and it's really a murderous war. We have seen a lot of the pictures, and for the viewers that have not seen the speech by President Zelensky today in the US Congress and the film that he has shown, it's really a must-see to see the death toll and the human toll of this war.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Ukraine is putting up incredible fight. They are brave and they are smart and they are really giving Russia a very, very hard time. Some estimates show that 40% of Russian vehicles have been destroyed by Ukrainian forces.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: So NATO will certainly continue to support Ukraine's government from NATO's territory, but with lethal aid.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: But right now, I don't see NATO going in.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Fingers crossed, because this would be a dangerous situation.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Fingers crossed that nothing worse happens in Ukraine anytime soon.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: What do you think about the news that the talks seem to be going relatively well and that one of the outcomes would be that Ukraine commits to not joining NATO, which would obviously mean that Russia has, I suppose, succeeded in some way by imposing its will on another country? not joining NATO, which would obviously mean that Russia has, I suppose, succeeded in some way by imposing its will on another country. I must say that I'm more from the school of, I believe it when I see it. This war was never about Ukraine joining or not joining NATO. This was a false narrative from the very beginning.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: It was clear that for Putin, the goal was to decapitate Ukraine's government and change the Ukrainian government into a puppet government. This is not happening anytime soon, and hopefully never, of course. So the real measure of progress will be a ceasefire to start with, but also an agreement to pull out Russian forces.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: And until we see this, it's really, yes, it's great to hear a bit of a different tone from Russia that is not demanding so-called denazification of Ukraine and is now going in a you know more mild direction but it's just I I believe it when I see it and I must say that most of the Russia experts here in Poland that have been looking at Russia for the last 30 years don't see it as a real progress, just yet at least.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Okay, Mikhail Baranowski, thank you very much for joining us from Warsaw.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Back to you in studio, Helena.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Shona, thanks a lot.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: A deep fake video of Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky urging citizens to lay down their arms and surrender has gone viral on social media. For more let's go over to Matthew in the Cube. The ongoing peace talks between Russia and Ukraine have opened the door for more viral misinformation to spread online. Now this video falsely claims to show Ukrainian president Volodymyr Zelensky. He appears to talk to Ukrainian citizens and tell them to surrender to the Russians and lay down their arms.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: One version of the video has amassed more than 85,000 views on Twitter.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: But this is what's known as a deepfake video.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: It has been manipulated using artificial intelligence.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: President Zelensky never says those words.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: A lot of the misinformation we've seen related to the war in Ukraine has been simpler than that.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: It's been videos and photos that have been taken out of context from different wars or other historical global events.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: But as Sam Gregory from Witness told me, that deepfake video is something different.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: This is the first deepfake that we've seen used in an intentional and perhaps broad-based deceptive way in the Ukraine conflict.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: It's not an effective deepfake. And I think that's partly because it's not an extremely well-made deepfake, but it's also because the Ukrainians have done a masterful job pre-bunking and then swiftly rebutting the deepfake. Now, President Zelensky himself has released a video on Instagram reiterating that that video is fake and the only people he is calling to surrender are the Russians.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: And what's more, two Ukrainian television channels who were hacked to show the message that that video contains, they have both also released statements saying again that the video is fake and echoing the words of the Ukrainian president.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: of the Ukrainian president.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: For weeks now, authorities in Kyiv have been warning citizens, warning them that they might come across manipulated videos online, calling on them to surrender.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: And Helena, analysts say that this strategy to try and pre-empt online misinformation, well, it's one that could possibly be used in the future by governments and politicians to pre-empt and debunk misinformation during times of crisis.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: All right, debunking the deepfakes.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Matthew, thank you so much.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: And that's the latest from us. I'll see you soon.
